newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong protesters sail for disputed islands.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong protesters sail for disputed islands.

text.p: Hong Kong protesters set sail on a rusty tanker on Sunday for disputed islands in the East China Sea to play cat-and-mouse with Japanese warships and to try to assert Chinese sovereignty over the isles.

Japan has claimed sovereign rights to the islands -- known in Japanese as the Senkakus and the Diaoyus in Chinese -- and refused to acknowledge that the dispute is still open for discussion with China.
Tokyo's claim dates to 1895, when Japan defeated China and seized Taiwan and other territories. China has claimed sovereignty over the islands for centuries.

The 2,800-tonne cargo tanker, Kien Hwa 2, carrying 18 anti-Japanese activists, 19 crew and 42 journalists, weaved its way through a colourful flotilla of yachts and other seacraft bobbing on one of the world's busiest shipping lanes as it began its three-day journey to the rocky outcrop.
A big banner emblazoned across the bow of the ship boldly stated the mission's intention. "We, the Chinese people, request that you, the Japanese, leave Chinese waters," it said.

"We will use every tactic and every strategy, such as hide-and-seek, to dodge the Japanese patrol boats and get onto those islands to raise the Chinese flag and restore our sovereignty," David Chan, convenor of the Alliance of the Worldwide Chinese for the Protection of the Diaoyu Islands, told Reuters shortly before the vessel departed.
In a parting gesture, Chan held aloft the big Chinese national flag he intends to firmly embed on the islands, and led his supporters in singing the Chinese national anthem.
His mission would not obey any orders to turn back if confronted by Japanese warships, he said.
"We are civilians, we have no weapons, no explosives, and our ship is only a cargo ship, it's not armed. We will not retreat," Chan told Reuters.
The protesters would use two rubber dinghies to try to beguile Japanese coast guard vessels.
"There may be five Japanese warships patrolling those waters around the islands, but it will not be so easy to catch us.
"We know this could be dangerous, but this is Chinese territory, and we have every right to land there," Chan said. "So what can the Japanese do to stop us?"
Japanese coast guard vessels have already turned back at least three vessels attempting similiar missions.
Tokyo's claim to the islands has whipped up anti-Japanese fervour in the tiny British colony, culminating in almost daily protest action.
Hong Kong returns to Chinese rule at midnight on June 30, next year.
